questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the doctor with a complaint of weakness in the lower extremities and waddling gait. Repetitive stimulation of the motor nerve facilitates the accumulation of Ca2+ in the nerve terminal and increases acetylcholine release, leading to an increase in muscle strength. The patient was diagnosed with small-cell cancer. Which autoimmune disorder is likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A young male with progressive lower limb weakness and waddling gait that improves with repeated stimulation, along with a history of small cell lung carcinoma, suggests Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome (LEMS).

Lambert-Eaton Syndrome (LEMS):

  • Autoimmune disorder targeting presynaptic P/Q-type voltage-gated calcium channels at the neuromuscular junction.
  • ↓ Calcium influx → ↓ Acetylcholine (ACh) release at synapse.
  • Repetitive stimulation leads to Ca²+ buildup → increased ACh release → transient strength improvement.
  • Strongly associated with small cell lung cancer (paraneoplastic syndrome).
  • Clinical features:
    • Proximal muscle weakness (legs > arms)
    • Autonomic symptoms: dry mouth, impotence
    • Hyporeflexia (reflexes may improve with exertion)

Explanation of Other Options:

Myasthenia Gravis (Option B): It involves postsynaptic ACh receptor antibodies and causes fatigability; symptoms worsen with repeated stimulation, unlike in LEMS.

Graves' Disease (Option C): This is an autoimmune thyroid disorder with no involvement of the neuromuscular junction or association with small cell lung cancer.

Hashimoto's Thyroiditis (Option D): Another thyroid autoimmune condition causing hypothyroidism, unrelated to neuromuscular junction pathology or paraneoplastic syndromes.

Key Takeaway:

Lambert-Eaton Syndrome is a presynaptic autoimmune disorder often associated with small cell lung cancer, characterised by proximal muscle weakness that improves with repetitive stimulation due to increased acetylcholine release.

choices.text: Na+ influx into the neuron → ACh release → End plate potential → Ca²+ influx into the nerve terminal
Action potential in nerve → Ca²+ entry into presynaptic terminal → ACh release → End plate potential
ACh binds muscle receptors → Ca²+ enters nerve terminal → Nerve action potential → End plate potential
End plate potential → ACh release → Ca²+ influx → Nerve action potential

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the correct sequence of events that occur at the neuromuscular junction leading to muscle activation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Nerve action potential causes Ca²+ influx into the presynaptic terminal, triggering ACh release, which generates an end plate potential in the muscle.

Sequence of events at the neuromuscular junction:

  • Motor neuron action potential
  • Calcium (Ca²+) entry into the nerve ending
  • Acetylcholine (ACh) release into the synaptic cleft
  • ACh binds to receptors on the muscle membrane
  • Sodium (Na+) entry into the muscle cell
  • Generation of endplate potential
  • Initiation of action potential in the muscle fiber
  • Propagation of the action potential along the muscle
  • Degradation of ACh by acetylcholinesterase

questions.text: A patient with botulism has flaccid paralysis. Which proteins are targeted by botulinum toxin in humans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by cleaving SNARE proteins, specifically synaptobrevin and SNAP-25 (in types A, C, and E), thus inhibiting acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.

Neurotransmitter Release and Botulinum Toxin:

  • Neurotransmitter Release Mechanism:
    • Docking proteins (SNARE proteins) mediate fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane for neurotransmitter release.
    • SNARE proteins include:
      • SNAP-25: Anchored to plasma membrane; pulls vesicle and membrane together.
      • Syntaxin: Located on plasma membrane; part of SNARE fusion complex.
      • Synaptobrevin (VAMP): Found on synaptic vesicle; initiates fusion with membrane.
  • Botulinum Toxin:
    • Types: A, B, C1, C2, D, E, F, G.
    • Types toxic to humans: A, B, E.
  • SNARE Proteins Inhibited by Botulinum Toxin:
  • Mechanism of Paralysis:
    • Botulinum toxins cleave SNARE proteins → inhibit vesicle docking and neurotransmitter (ACh) release → cause flaccid paralysis.

Key Takeaway:

Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by cleaving SNARE proteins (especially synaptobrevin and SNAP-25), thereby blocking acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.

choices.text: Increased number of acetylcholine release sites in the presynaptic neuron
Increased production of acetylcholine vesicles in presynaptic neurons
Marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of increased acetylcholine sensitivity in a denervated skeletal muscle following a nerve injury?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

After denervation, nicotinic acetylcholine receptors proliferate across a broader region of the muscle membrane (not just the motor end plate), leading to increased sensitivity to acetylcholine.

  • Denervation hypersensitivity (also called supersensitivity) occurs when a motor nerve to skeletal muscle is cut and degenerates, leading to increased muscle sensitivity to acetylcholine (ACh).
  • The biceps muscle is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve (roots C5-C7 of the brachial plexus). Injury to this nerve affects motor supply to the biceps.
  • After denervation, there is marked proliferation of nicotinic receptors across a wider region of the neuromuscular junction, increasing sensitivity to ACh.
  • ACh production and release are reduced, as nerve impulses no longer reach the terminal due to the severed axon.
  • Neurotrophins (like nerve growth factor) aid in neuronal recovery and survival, but do not affect receptor sensitivity

Explanation of other options:

Increased number of acetylcholine release sites in the presynaptic neuron(Option A):
This is incorrect because in a denervated muscle, the presynaptic neuron is absent or damaged, so there can be no increase in acetylcholine release sites.

Increased production of acetylcholine vesicles in presynaptic neurons(Option B):
If the nerve is injured and the muscle is denervated, the presynaptic terminal is not functional or may have degenerated, so vesicle production is actually reduced or absent, not increased.

Increased levels of neurotrophins(Option C):
Neurotrophins support neuron survival and axonal growth, but they do not directly cause acetylcholine sensitivity in muscle. Their role is more related to nerve regeneration than to receptor proliferation on muscle fibers.

Key Takeaway:

Denervation causes upregulation and widespread distribution of nicotinic ACh receptors, making the muscle more sensitive to acetylcholine or related stimuli.

choices.text: It is triggered by the release of acetylcholine from about 60 or more vesicles by each nerve impulse
MEPP frequency is inversely related to extracellular Mg²+ concentration
MEPP frequency is directly related to extracellular Ca²+ concentration

questions.text: A miniature end plate potential (MEPP) is recorded at the neuromuscular junction of a resting muscle. Which of the following statements regarding MEPP is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

MEPP occurs spontaneously at rest due to the release of a single vesicle of acetylcholine, not multiple vesicles triggered by a nerve impulse.

Miniature End Plate Potential (MEPP):

  • Miniature End Plate Potential (MEPP) is a small depolarizing potential (~0.5 mV) seen as a tiny spike.
  • It occurs at rest due to the random release of small quanta of acetylcholine from the nerve terminal.(Option D ruled out)
  • The size of the quanta of acetylcholine released:
    • Increases with Ca²+ concentration(Option C ruled out)
    • Decreases with Mg²+ concentration(Option B ruled out)
  • A nerve action potential triggers release of acetylcholine from ~60 synaptic vesicles.
  • Each vesicle contains about 10,000 molecules of acetylcholine.
  • This collective release produces a depolarizing end plate potential in the muscle fiber.

Key Takeaway:

MEPP is caused by spontaneous release of a single vesicle of ACh, not by nerve impulses or multiple vesicle releases.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presents with difficulty in breathing, ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, and dysphagia. He is a known case of myasthenia gravis. Which of the following treatments is not useful for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Muscarine acts on muscarinic receptors, not the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors affected in myasthenia gravis, making it ineffective in treatment.

Myasthenia gravis:

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder that impairs neuromuscular transmission.
  • It involves autoantibodies against nicotinic ACh receptors, leading to receptor destruction or functional blockade.
  • Nicotinic receptors are located at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Muscarine, a substance found in mushrooms, acts only on muscarinic receptors, not nicotinic. → Ineffective in myasthenia gravis. (Option B)
  • Neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, increases acetylcholine at the NMJ → improves muscle strength. (Option D)
  • Prednisone, an immunosuppressant, reduces antibody production → clinically beneficial. (Option C)
  • Thymectomy is helpful, as the thymus may contribute to disease pathogenesis by supplying autoreactive T-cells. → indicated treatment. (Option A)

Key Takeaway:

In myasthenia gravis, treatment targets nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction; muscarine (which acts on muscarinic receptors) is ineffective.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with muscle weakness and atrophy. On examination and subsequent genetic testing, he is found to have an X-linked disorder with complete absence of the dystrophin protein in his muscles. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical features of progressive muscle weakness, atrophy, and absence of dystrophin in an X-linked pattern point toward the diagnosis of Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD):

  • X-linked disorder where dystrophin is completely absent, leading to severe muscle weakness and death by ~30 years.

Clinical features:

  • Less common
  • 1:30000 live male birth
  • less severe
  • Family history: atypical MD
  • Similar and less severe than DMD
  • age of onset is >7 years
  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf
  • Equinous and varus foot
  • High rate of scoliosis
  • Less frequent cardiac involvement

Explanation of other options:

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option B) has reduced or abnormal dystrophin, making it a milder form of dystrophinopathy.

Tibialis muscular dystrophy (Option C) involves a mutation in titin, affecting protein stability.

McArdle syndrome (Option D) is a metabolic myopathy caused by enzyme mutations affecting muscle metabolism.

Key Takeaway:

Complete absence of dystrophin in an X-linked disorder with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy strongly indicates Duchenne muscular dystrophy.

questions.text: During muscle relaxation, calcium ions are actively transported from the cytosol back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR). Which of the following proteins is directly responsible for this ATP-dependent reuptake process?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SERCA protein actively pumps calcium ions back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum using ATP, facilitating muscle relaxation.

SERCA:

  • Full form: Sarcoplasmic Reticulum Ca²+-ATPase.
  • Function: Pumps calcium ions actively from the cytosol back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) during muscle relaxation.
  • ATP-dependent: Requires ATP to transport Ca²+ against its concentration gradient.
  • Concentration ability: Can concentrate Ca²+ up to 10,000-fold inside the sarcoplasmic tubules.
  • Role in muscle function: By removing Ca²+ from the cytosol, it allows detachment of actin and myosin, promoting muscle relaxation.

Explanation of other options:

Dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) (Option A): DHPR is a voltage-sensitive receptor on the T-tubule membrane that triggers calcium release by activating the ryanodine receptor during muscle contraction, not relaxation.

Ryanodine receptor (Option B): This receptor is located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum and is responsible for releasing Ca²+ into the cytosol during contraction, not reuptake.

Calsequestrin (Option D): Calsequestrin is a calcium-binding protein inside the SR that stores Ca²+, but it does not transport or pump it.

Key Takeaway:

SERCA is the ATP-dependent pump responsible for the reuptake of Ca²+ into the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which is essential for muscle relaxation.

choices.text: 1 → b → I, 2 → c → III, 3 → a → II
1 → c → III, 2 → a → II, 3 → b → I
1 → a → II, 2 → b → I, 3 → c → III
1 → b → III, 2 → c → II, 3 → a → I

questions.text: Match the following fibre types with their corresponding motor units and functional characteristics.
questions.solution: Explanation:

choices.text: Repetitive firing of action potentials from autonomic nerves
Continuous phosphorylation of myosin light chains
Formation of actin-myosin cross-bridges that remain attached with low ATP use
Increased recruitment of fast-twitch motor units maintains contraction

questions.text: A 40-year-old man undergoes surgery for chronic hypertension. During the procedure, the surgeon observes persistent contraction in the wall of a medium-sized artery, even with minimal neural input. Despite low ATP consumption, the vessel maintains tone for several hours. Which of the following best explains this sustained contraction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ability of smooth muscle (like in arterial walls) to maintain long-term contraction with minimal energy consumption is due to the latch state, where actin-myosin cross-bridges remain attached even after dephosphorylation, allowing sustained tone with low ATP usage.

Latch Mechanism in Smooth Muscle:

  • Latch mechanism is a phenomenon unique to smooth muscle.
  • It involves myosin cross-bridges remaining attached to actin even after cytoplasmic Ca²+ levels fall.
  • Enables sustained contraction with minimal energy use.
  • Especially vital in maintaining vascular tone (e.g., arterioles).
  • Energy usage is extremely low, sometimes as little as 1/300 compared to skeletal muscle contraction.
  • Commonly observed in:
    • Blood vessels
    • Airways
    • Gastrointestinal tract
    • Urinary bladder

Explanation of Other Options:

Repetitive firing of action potentials from autonomic nerves (Option A): While autonomic nerves can initiate smooth muscle contraction, sustained contraction is maintained independently by the latch state even with minimal neural input.

Continuous phosphorylation of myosin light chains (Option B): Phosphorylation is important for initiating contraction, but the latch state maintains contraction without ongoing phosphorylation, allowing energy-efficient sustained tone.

Increased recruitment of fast-twitch motor units (Option D): This concept applies only to skeletal muscle, not smooth muscle. Also, fast-twitch fibers fatigue rapidly, making them unsuitable for long-lasting contraction like that seen in blood vessels.

Key takeaway:

Latch state in smooth muscle allows prolonged contraction with minimal ATP, crucial for vascular tone maintenance.

questions.text: A 21-year-old physiology student is observing skeletal muscle responses during an experiment. The muscle is electrically stimulated twice in rapid succession. The second stimulus is applied before the muscle has completely relaxed from the first. As a result, the second contraction produces a greater force than the first, as shown in the graph. Which of the following physiological phenomena is being demonstrated?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The increase in force with the second rapid stimulus before complete relaxation indicates summation, where residual calcium allows more cross-bridge cycling.

Summation in Muscle Contraction:

  • When a muscle is stimulated repeatedly at low frequency, responses add up due to a beneficial effect, producing a stronger contraction known as summation.
  • Mechanism:
    • After the first contraction, Ca²+ remains in the sarcoplasm.
    • A second stimulus before full Ca²+ reuptake into the sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) adds more calcium.
    • This leads to increased actin-myosin cross-bridge cycling → stronger contraction.
  • Summation Doesn't Occur in Cardiac Muscle:
    • Cardiac muscle has a long absolute refractory period due to its plateau phase in action potentials.
    • This prevents a second action potential before the first contraction ends.
    • Hence, summation and tetanus are physiologically impossible in cardiac tissue.

Explanation of other options:

Incomplete tetanus (Option B): This occurs with higher-frequency stimulation where partial relaxation is allowed between contractions, unlike the two rapid single stimuli seen in summation.

Complete tetanus (Option C): Requires very high-frequency stimulation with no relaxation at all, leading to a sustained contraction, not the brief increase in force after a second stimulus as seen in the scenario.

Fatigue (Option D): In fatigue, muscle force decreases with repeated stimulation, whereas in summation, force increases with closely spaced stimuli.

Key Takeaway:

Summation occurs when a second stimulus is applied during partial relaxation, causing a stronger contraction due to additive calcium effects.

questions.text: The graph below shows a characteristic action potential recorded during a physiology experiment. Which of the following tissues most likely shows this type of action potential?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The action potential shown lacks a plateau phase and has a quick repolarization, characteristic of skeletal muscle fibers.

  • Resting membrane potential is a primary differentiating feature between nerve and muscle action potentials.
  • Nerve fibers have a resting membrane potential of −70 mV. (Option A ruled out.)
  • Skeletal muscle has a resting membrane potential of −90 mV and a short-duration action potential without a plateau phase.
  • Cardiac muscle also has a resting potential of −90 mV, but its action potential shows a plateau phase. (Option C ruled out.)
  • Sinoatrial (SA) node has a resting potential around −55 mV and shows slow depolarization instead of a sharp spike. (Option D ruled ou.t)

Key Takeaway:

Skeletal muscle action potentials are short, have a rapid upstroke and downstroke, and do not exhibit a plateau phase like cardiac muscle.

choices.text: Cardiac myocytes exhibit recruitment of motor units in proportion to stimulus strength
Cardiac muscle fibers contract in a graded manner depending on calcium influx
Cardiac tissue responds with a full contraction once threshold is reached due to the all-or-none law
Cardiac action potentials are generated by summation of multiple subthreshold stimuli

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease presents with ventricular tachycardia. During synchronised cardioversion, it is observed that the myocardium responds fully once the electrical stimulus reaches a threshold, but not to subthreshold stimuli. This behavior is best explained by which of the following physiological principles specific to cardiac muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The scenario illustrates that cardiac muscle contracts fully when the threshold is reached, which reflects the all-or-none law.

  • Cardiac muscle acts as a functional syncytium due to the presence of gap junctions.
  • Action potentials spread rapidly through these gap junctions, enabling synchronous contraction of connected fibers.
  • Once the threshold potential is reached, the entire myocardial unit contracts maximally.
  • This uniform response reflects the all-or-none law, meaning no partial contractions occur in cardiac muscle.

Explanation of other options:

Cardiac myocytes exhibit recruitment of motor units in proportion to stimulus strength(Option A): This is true for skeletal muscle, not cardiac. In skeletal muscle, stronger stimuli recruit more motor units, leading to graded contraction. Cardiac muscle has no motor units, it's innervated by autonomic fibers that modulate rate and force, not recruit units.

Cardiac muscle fibers contract in a graded manner depending on calcium influx(Option B): In cardiac muscle, intracellular Ca²+ concentration does influence contractile force, but this is regulated by physiological factors (e.g., sympathetic stimulation), not the strength of the initial stimulus. that cardiac output can be modulated by Ca²+, but the action potential still follows all-or-none behavior

Cardiac action potentials are generated by summation of multiple subthreshold stimuli(Option D): This describes temporal or spatial summation, which is a feature of skeletal muscle and neurons, not cardiac muscle.

In cardiac tissue:

  • Each action potential is a distinct, all-or-none event.
  • Due to the long absolute refractory period, summation and tetany are physiologically impossible
  • Key Takeaway:
  • Cardiac muscle follows the all-or-none law, meaning once the threshold is reached, the entire myocardium contracts fully, without partial or graded responses.

choices.text: Closing of fast sodium channels and opening of potassium channels
Opening of calcium channels and closing of fast potassium channels
Closing of calcium channels and opening of slow potassium channels

questions.text: The blue line in the graph below represents a plateau phase in the cardiac action potential. This phase is primarily due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The blue line in the graph represents the plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac muscle action potential, which occurs due to the opening of L-type calcium channels allowing calcium influx and closing of fast potassium channels, thereby reducing potassium efflux.

Phases of Cardiac Muscle Action Potential:

  • Phase 0: Rapid Depolarization
    • Triggered by opening of fast voltage-gated Na+ channels
    • Na+ influx causes a sharp rise in membrane potential
    • Ends when Na+ channels inactivate
  • Phase 1: Initial Repolarization
    • Na+ channels close (inactivate)
    • Transient outward K+ channels (Ito) open briefly → K+ efflux
    • Results in a slight decrease in membrane potential
  • Phase 2: Plateau Phase
    • Caused by:
      • Opening of L-type Ca²+ channels → Ca²+ influx
      • Closing of fast K+ channels → reduced K+ efflux
    • The balance between Ca²+ influx and K+ efflux maintains plateau
  • Phase 3: Repolarization
    • Calcium channels close
    • Delayed rectifier K+ channels open fully → K+ efflux increases
    • Membrane potential returns to resting level
  • Phase 4: Resting Membrane Potential
    • Maintained by:
      • Inward rectifier K+ channels
      • Na+/K+ ATPase pump
    • Low Na+ permeability helps stabilize resting state

Key Takeaway:
The plateau phase (Phase 2) of the cardiac action potential is maintained by opening of L-type calcium channels and closure of fast potassium channels, allowing sustained depolarization crucial for effective cardiac muscle contraction and preventing tetany.

choices.text: Nuclear factor from activated T cells (NFAT)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male athlete with a predominance of fast-twitch muscle fibers wants to improve his endurance for an upcoming marathon. Which transcription factor would be most beneficial to promote slow-twitch fiber transformation and improve long-distance performance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

NFAT promotes the transformation of fast-twitch fibers into slow-twitch oxidative fibers, enhancing endurance capacity, ideal for marathon training.

NFAT (Nuclear factor of activated T-cells):

  • Enhances transcription of slow-twitch muscle genes
  • Promotes transition from fast-twitch to slow-twitch fibers

Relevance to Marathon Training:

  • Slow-twitch fibers are more efficient for endurance activities like marathons
  • NFAT activation supports endurance adaptation by promoting slow-twitch fiber dominance

MURF2 (Ubiquitin ligase): (Option B):

  • Inhibits transcription
  • Leads to decreased protein synthesis
  • Promotes increased protein degradation

PI3K (Phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase) (Option C):

  • Inhibits eukaryotic translation initiation factor
  • Activates caspase-3, promoting protein degradation
  • Contributes to reduced protein synthesis

Key Takeaway:

Targeting NFAT helps in adapting muscle fiber types towards fatigue-resistant, oxidative slow fibres, improving long-distance running performance.

questions.text: Look at the following electron microscopic image of a muscle fibre. What is the structure marked with a blue arrow?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The blue arrow points to the Z-line where actinin anchors actin filaments, a hallmark feature visible in electron microscopy of skeletal muscle.

  • Skeletal muscle contains four main contractile proteins:
    • Actin
    • Myosin
    • Troponin
    • Tropomyosin
  • Tropomyosin is located on actin filaments and interacts with troponin to regulate contraction. (Option A)
  • Structural proteins in skeletal muscle include:
    • Desmin
    • Titin
    • Actinin
  • Actinin binds actin filaments to the Z-lines, helping anchor them in place. (Option C)
  • Titin (the largest known protein): (Option D)
    • Connects Z-lines to M-lines
    • Provides scaffolding and elasticity to the sarcomere
  • Desmin: (Option B)
    • Strengthens Z-lines
    • Connects Z-lines to the plasma membrane
    • Acts as a cell adhesion molecule to maintain structural integrity

choices.text: It covers the myosin binding site on actin at rest
Inhibits the interaction between actin and myosin
Binds with Ca++ to initiate the muscle contraction

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about troponin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Troponin itself does not cover the myosin binding site; tropomyosin does that, while troponin regulates its position in response to calcium binding.

  • Actin and myosin are the two principal contractile proteins in muscle.
  • Two regulatory proteins are also present: tropomyosin and troponin.
  • Each thin filament contains:
    • ~300-400 actin molecules
    • ~40-60 tropomyosin molecules
  • Troponin is composed of small globular units located at intervals along tropomyosin.
  • Troponin has three subunits:
    • Troponin T (TnT): Binds to tropomyosin, helping position the troponin complex. (Option A)
    • Troponin C (TnC): Binds to Ca²+ to initiate contraction by causing a conformational change. (Option D)
    • Troponin I (TnI): Acts as an inhibitor, preventing actin-myosin interaction at rest. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Troponin does not directly block actin's myosin-binding sites; tropomyosin does, under the control of the troponin-calcium complex.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male was planning to build his career in sports. But as he initiated fitness training, he was not able to do it for more than a few minutes. As he visited the doctor, he was found to have exercise intolerance. He has a problem with the metabolism of carbohydrates and proteins in the muscle. He was diagnosed with metabolic myopathy. In the list below, which is metabolic myopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient has exercise intolerance due to impaired carbohydrate metabolism in muscle, which is characteristic of McArdle syndrome, a metabolic myopathy.

  • McArdle syndrome is a metabolic myopathy.
  • It is caused by a mutation in genes coding for enzymes involved in metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins to CO2 and H2O in muscles.
  • These metabolic processes are essential for ATP production during muscle activity.

Clinical Features of McArdle syndrome

  • Exercise intolerance
  • Muscle cramps and pain, especially during strenuous activity
  • Early fatigue
  • Second-wind phenomenon: improvement in exercise tolerance after a brief rest due to switch to blood glucose and fatty acids
  • No rise in lactate during ischemic forearm test
  • Myoglobinuria (dark-colored urine after exercise)
  • Possible renal failure (due to rhabdomyolysis)

Explanation of other options:

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option B): It is a dystrophinopathy, not a metabolic myopathy; dystrophin is present but reduced or abnormal.

Desmin-related myopathy (Option C): It is a structural myopathy, not metabolic; caused by defects in desmin, a cytoskeletal protein.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy (Option D): A severe X-linked dystrophinopathy, not metabolic; caused by absence of dystrophin leading to progressive muscle degeneration.

Key Takeaway:
McArdle syndrome is a metabolic myopathy caused by deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase, leading to exercise intolerance and muscle fatigue due to impaired glycogen breakdown.

choices.text: Ligand-gated calcium channel on T tubule
Voltage-gated calcium channel on T tubule
Ligand-gated calcium channel on L tubule
Voltage-gated calcium channel on L tubule

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of the dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) in skeletal muscle contraction?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The dihydropyridine receptor (DHPR) is a voltage-gated calcium channel located on the T-tubule membrane that responds to depolarization and mechanically interacts with ryanodine receptors on the sarcoplasmic reticulum to trigger calcium release.

  • Ryanodine receptor (RyR), a ligand-gated Ca²++ channel located on the L tubule.
  • Ca²+ is the natural ligand that activates RyR.
  • In cardiac muscle, Ca²+ influx through DHPR triggers Ca²-induced Ca²+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum via RyR.
  • DHPR acts as a voltage sensor in the T-tubule membrane.
  • In skeletal muscle, DHPR triggers Ca²+ release from the SR through direct mechanical interaction with RyR.
  • The initial Ca²+ release is amplified by further Ca²-induced Ca²+ release.

Key Takeaway:

DHPR is a voltage-gated calcium channel on T-tubules that plays a key role in excitation-contraction coupling in skeletal muscle.

questions.text: The following is a simple muscle twitch in the gastrocnemius muscle. Recognise the tetanising frequency in this muscle.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

At a stimulation frequency of 60-70 Hz, the gastrocnemius muscle shows fused sustained contraction without relaxation between twitches, indicating tetanus.

  • Tetanizing frequency refers to the stimulation rate required to produce a sustained muscle contraction, called tetanus.
  • In the given graph, the contraction period is measured as 15 mm.
  • Paper speed is given as 1000 mm/sec, meaning 1000 mm on the graph equals 1 second.
  • 15mm movement takes 15/1000 = 0.015second = 15msec
  • Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period (in seconds) = 1*1000/15 = 66 Hz
  • Hence, the correct answer is Option D (60-70 Hz).

Key Takeaway:

  • Tetanizing frequency = 1 / contraction period (in seconds).

choices.text: Walking matches with type of contraction shown in the figure
Holding a bucket filled with 10 litres of water is an example of this type of contraction
It is an isometric type of muscle contraction

questions.text: Observe the following image and identify which of the following statements is not true regarding the type of muscle contraction shown.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The figure illustrates isometric contraction, where the muscle length remains constant despite the generation of tension. Walking involves isotonic contractions, where muscle length changes to move.

  • Muscle contraction usually causes shortening of muscle fibres.
  • Due to elastic and viscous elements, muscles can contract without a noticeable change in length.
  • This type of contraction is called an isometric contraction: (Option C)
    • Muscle length remains constant.
    • Tension in the muscle increases.
  • Example: Holding a bucket of 10 litres of water involves isometric contraction (increased tension, no change in length). (Option B)
  • In isotonic contraction:
    • Muscle length decreases.
    • Tension remains nearly the same.
    • Example: Walking involves isotonic contractions.
  • In isometric contraction, the work done is nearly zero, since there is no change in muscle length.

Key Takeaway:
Isometric contraction involves increased muscle tension without a change in muscle length, as seen when holding a heavy object still.

choices.text: Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length
Maximum tension is generated when actin and myosin filaments do not overlap at all
Muscle generates maximum force only at maximal stretch
Maximum cross-bridge formation occurs at optimal sarcomere length

questions.text: During a muscle physiology experiment, a skeletal muscle fiber is electrically stimulated at different lengths. It is observed that the maximum isometric tension is produced at a particular muscle length. This observation can be best explained by which of the following principles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Maximum isometric tension is produced when actin and myosin filaments overlap optimally, allowing maximal cross-bridge formation.

  • Maximum active tension in skeletal muscle is generated when the sarcomere length is about 2.0 to 2.2 µm.
  • At this optimal length, actin and myosin filaments overlap ideally, allowing for the maximum number of cross-bridges to form.
  • This length is referred to as the optimal muscle length.
  • It correlates with the maximum isometric contraction force.

Explanation of Other Options:

Passive tension is highest at resting muscle length(Option A): Passive tension arises when a muscle is stretched beyond its resting length due to the elastic components(like titin and connective tissue). At resting length, passive tension is minimal or zero. Passive tension increases only when the muscle is stretched, not at rest.

Maximum tension is generated when actin and myosin filaments do not overlap at all(Option B): If there is no overlap between actin and myosin filaments, no cross-bridges can form. Without cross-bridge formation, active tension cannot be produced. This happens when the muscle is overstretched beyond optimal length.

Muscle generates maximum force only at maximal stretch (Option C): When a sarcomere is stretched too far, actin and myosin filaments barely overlap, so few cross-bridges can form, resulting in very low tension. Thus, maximum force is not generated at maximal stretch, but rather at optimal length, before excessive stretch occurs.

Key Takeaway:

Maximum isometric tension in skeletal muscle is produced when sarcomere length allows optimal overlap between actin and myosin, enabling maximum cross-bridge formation.

questions.text: Which of the following types of muscle fibers is characterized by a low innervation ratio, making it suitable for fine motor control and sustained activity?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

S fibers (slow-twitch fibers) have a low innervation ratio, meaning each motor neuron innervates fewer muscle fibers. This allows for precise and sustained contractions, ideal for activities like posture maintenance.

Motor Unit Types:

  • S Fibers (Type I):
    • Low innervation ratio, slow contraction speed, oxidative metabolism.
    • High fatigue resistance, recruited first for low-intensity tasks (e.g., standing).
  • FR Fibers (Type IIa):
    • Moderate innervation ratio (~200-400 fibers), fast contraction, oxidative + glycolytic metabolism.
    • Moderate fatigue resistance, recruited for moderate activities (e.g., walking).
  • FF Fibers (Type IIb):
    • High innervation ratio (~300-800 fibers), fast contraction, glycolytic metabolism.
    • Low fatigue resistance, recruited for high-intensity tasks (e.g., running, jumping).

Explanation of other options:

Type II Fibers (Option D): Incorrect because Type II fibers (IIa and IIb) have higher innervation ratios and are suited for powerful, less precise movements, not fine motor control or sustained activity.

Key Takeaway:

S fibers (slow-twitch fibers) have a low innervation ratio, enabling fine motor control and fatigue-resistant sustained contractions.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old male sustains a clean transection of a peripheral nerve in the upper limb following a traumatic accident. Which of the following physiological changes are expected in the denervated skeletal muscle?
(1): Muscle atrophy
(2): Denervation hypersensitivity
(3): Spontaneous fibrillations seen on electromyography (EMG)
(4): Excitability to direct electrical stimulation increases over time
questions.solution:
Explanation:

After nerve transection, the denervated muscle shows atrophy, hypersensitivity to acetylcholine, and fibrillations on EMG; however, excitability to direct stimulation decreases over time due to muscle fibre degeneration.

  • In healthy individuals, muscle contraction requires motor nerve stimulation.
  • Peripheral nerve injury causes lower motor neuron paralysis.
  • A denervated muscle undergoes:
    • Muscle atrophy due to a lack of neural input.
    • Denervation hypersensitivity, i.e., increased sensitivity to circulating acetylcholine.
    • Spontaneous fibrillations, which are fine, irregular muscle contractions detectable on EMG.
  • Fibrillations disappear once the motor nerve regenerates and reinnervates the muscle.

Explanation of the incorrect statement:

Excitability to direct electrical stimulation increases over time (Statement 4): The statement is incorrect because, over time, denervated muscles undergo membrane instability and fibre degeneration, which reduces their responsiveness to direct electrical stimulation, not increases it.

choices.text: It has dense bodies in the cytoplasm
Sarcoplasmic reticulum is less extensive in smooth muscle
Troponin is not present in smooth muscle

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes biopsy of a gastrointestinal mass. Histology reveals spindle-shaped, non-striated muscle fibres with central nuclei and no visible sarcomeres. Which of the following features most accurately differentiates this muscle type from skeletal muscle, based on its structural and functional properties?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The muscle described is smooth muscle, which differs from skeletal muscle in several ways:

  • It contains dense bodies instead of Z-lines for anchoring actin filaments. (Option A)
  • The sarcoplasmic reticulum is less developed, relying more on extracellular calcium. (Option B)
  • Troponin is absent; smooth muscle contraction is regulated via calmodulin and MLCK (myosin light chain kinase) (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Smooth muscle differs from skeletal muscle by lacking troponin, having dense bodies instead of Z-lines, and possessing a less extensive sarcoplasmic reticulum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female was admitted to the emergency department due to dizziness followed by loss of consciousness. Evaluation with ECG reveals a prolonged QT interval suggestive of long QT syndrome. This condition is most commonly associated with mutations in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Long QT syndrome results from mutations in potassium, sodium, or calcium channel genes that delay cardiac repolarisation and prolong the QT interval.

Long QT Syndrome (LQTS):

  • Long QT Syndrome (LQTS) is characterised by a prolonged QT interval on ECG.
  • Clinical features: irregular heartbeats, syncope, seizures, cardiac arrest, or sudden death.
  • Common cause: Genetic mutations; may also be drug-induced.
  • 90% of genetic cases involve mutations in K+ channel genes: KCNQ1 or KCNH2.
  • Other genetic mutations include:
    • Na+ channel gene: SCN5A
    • Ca2+ channel gene: CACNA1C
  • Drugs causing QT prolongation (mnemonic: ABCDE FAMOus QT drugs):
    • Antiarrhythmics (Class IA, III)
    • Bacterial drugs: Macrolides, Fluoroquinolones
    • CNS drugs: Antipsychotics, Antidepressants
    • Drugs for nausea: Ondansetron
    • Endocrine drugs: Methadone
    • FAMO: Fluconazole, Azithromycin, Methadone, Ondansetron

choices.text: It has fewer gap junctions than multiunit smooth muscle
It has fewer en passant junctions on cells than multiunit smooth muscle
Single-unit smooth muscle is found in the iris muscle of the eye
Single-unit muscle fibres are syncytial, allowing widespread contractions

questions.text: Which of the following best characterises single-unit (visceral) smooth muscle compared to multi-unit smooth muscle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Single-unit smooth muscle cells are connected by numerous gap junctions, allowing them to function as a functional syncytium, resulting in coordinated, widespread contractions. In contrast, multi-unit smooth muscle (e.g., in the iris) has fewer gap junctions and contracts independently.

  • Smooth muscle is classified into two types:
    • Single-unit (unitary) smooth muscle
    • Multi-unit smooth muscle
  • Single-unit smooth muscle:
    • Found in hollow viscera like the intestinal wall, uterus, and ureter
    • Contains low-resistance gap junctions between cells
    • Functions as a syncytium, allowing widespread coordinated contraction
    • Has en passant junctions on fewer cells; excitation spreads via gap junctions
    • Resembles cardiac muscle in contractile behaviour
  • Multi-unit smooth muscle:
    • Found in the iris muscles, the airways of the lungs
    • Each cell has its own en passant nerve ending
    • Lacks functional syncytium; contractions are more independent and localised
  • In blood vessels, both types of smooth muscle cells may be present.

Explanation of other options:

It has fewer gap junctions than multiunit smooth muscle (Option A): Single-unit smooth muscle has more gap junctions, which allow coordinated contractions; multi-unit smooth muscle has few or no gap junctions.

It has fewer en passant junctions on cells than multiunit smooth muscle(Option B): single-unit smooth muscle has more en passant junctions in the form of diffuse innervation, one axon can influence many muscle cells via neurotransmitter release.

Single-unit smooth muscle is found in the iris muscle of the eye (Option C): The iris muscle contains multi-unit smooth muscle, which allows precise, graded contractions without syncytial activity.

Key Takeaway:
